author: Mary Ward
title: TV's most famous addresses
text:
Jerry Seinfeld and associates in Apartment 5A, 129 West 81st Street, on New York's Upper West Side. Photo: Network Ten 
The relationship we share with our favourite television characters is an intimate one: we let them into our living rooms, and, often they let us into theirs.
But, there are some television shows in which the characters' home is more than just a set, it's a character of itself. A place where some of the show's biggest revelations, or most touching moments, took place.
Although you might not remember the exact street address, they're the sort of places you can find without using your GPS. Here are 10 of the most memorable residences on the box.
Ramsay Street, where Helen and Karl Kennedy have starred in Neighbours. Photo: Pat Scala 
742 Evergreen Terrace ( The Simpsons )  Its paint colour may have shifted from light pink to a slightly more brown hue, but the Simpson family home has remained as a constant fixture throughout the show's 26 seasons. Despite its dilapidated appearance, the Simpsons' four-bedroom abode is surprisingly structurally sound: when a hurricane passed through the town of Springfield, 742 remained standing while 744 (the house of the Simpsons' do-gooder neighbour Ned Flanders) was completely destroyed.
Advertisement Wisteria Lane ( Desperate Housewives ) The suburban cul-de-sac in which the middle-class ladies of the Desperate Housewives cast lived, lunched, and looked at pool boys came to be as well known as the show itself. Interestingly, the street we know as Wisteria Lane is actually a set inside Hollywood's Universal Studios called Colonial Street, and has been used in productions ranging from Gremlins and Buffy the Vampire Slayer , to the film clip for Smash Mouth's All Star .
Apartment 5A, 129 West 81st Street ( Seinfeld )  Jerry Seinfeld's apartment on New York's Upper West Side, with its purple walls and sky blue couches, was the place where ... nothing much happened. The apartment was recreated for five days as part of a Seinfeld exhibit in June, giving fans the chance to hang out in apartment 5A.
The cast of Desperate Housewives in Wisteria Lane. Photo: Supplied 
1882 Gerard Street ( Full House )  The Tanner family's three-bed, three-bath San Francisco detached home was the place where Jesse and Joey helped Danny Tanner to raise his three daughters: D.J., Stephanie and Michelle. The actual San Fran house used for the show's exterior shots last sold in 2006 for $US1.85 million ($2.57 million) although it is estimated that its value has nearly tripled since then.
508 Saint Cloud Road ( The Fresh Prince of Bel Air )  Every prince needs his castle and for Philadelphia-born Will Smith (played by, you guessed it, Will Smith) 508 Saint Cloud Road was where he came to sit on his throne as the Fresh Prince of Bel Air. Although there is indeed an insanely large Bel Air mansion sitting at 508 Saint Cloud Road it is, alas, not the Roman-columned palace that was occupied by the Banks family.
7 Gordon Street ( The Sullivans ) 
The Sullivans outside 7 Gordon Street. Photo: Supplied 
The Sullivans' weatherboard villa in Melbourne's Camberwell was actually a house located three kilometres away in the suburb of Canterbury. The house – where Dave and Grace raised their three children through WWII – is no longer standing, having been replaced by townhouses.
4222 Clinton Way ( The Brady Bunch ) 
The family of a man named Brady and a lovely lady lived at 4222 Clinton Way. The house – which is a real house in Los Angeles' San Fernando Valley – was reportedly chosen as the residence of the eight Bradys and their housekeeper, Alice, because series creator Sherwood Schwartz thought it looked like the kind of house where an architect would live.
The Flintstone family, residents of 342 Gravelpit Terrace. Photo: Supplied 
342 Gravelpit Terrace ( The Flintstones ) 
Fred Flintstone and his wife Wilma live next to Barney and Betty Rubble on Gravelpit Terrace, in a one-storey abode with a large, grassy garden surrounded by palm trees. No word on how the grass stays that green in the middle of the desert.
245 East 73rd Street ( Sex and the City ) 
Carrie Bradshaw's Manhattan red brick is why you should never believe what you see on TV. Comparable one-bedroom, shabby chic apartments in NYC (between Park and Madison avenues, no less) rent for about $US3500 ($4860) a month. For someone who seems to just write one romance column a week, that's a lot of dollars. Was she managing hedge funds on the side?
28 Ramsay Street ( Neighbours ) 
Originally owned by Des Clarke, in 1994 Helen and Karl Kennedy moved into No. 28 on Australian TV's most famous street, and they have been there ever since. While the house has seen various residents come and go – the Kennedy's three kids, a foreign exchange student, as well as literally anyone within a one kilometre radius going through some sort of relationship trauma – Helen and Karl seem unlikely to leave any time soon.
